Award.AwardTitle: Differential Equations on Singular Spaces and Asymptotic Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves several geometric problems giving rise to linear and nonlinear differential equations on noncompact manifolds. The PI has worked in recent years on constant scalar curvature, constant Ricci curvature, Gauss curvature flow, and equations of mean curvature type. She is above all interested in such questions in the presence of singularities - sharp corners, cones, and edges. Promising new directions generated by this work will be carried out during the grant period. Curvature conditions produce nonlinear equations, which are typically very challenging in noncompact and singular settings. Questions to be pursued include extensions of recent work carried out with R. Mazzeo and Y. Rubinstein regarding the existence and the nature of Kaehler-Einstein metrics with conical singularities on a compact, complex manifold. The PI intends likewise to pursue further work in the area of constant scalar curvature metrics with conical singularities. Earlier joint work with J. Rowlett focused on the case of negative curvature; the PI now intends to continue these investigations into the cases of zero and positive curvature. In addition to these nonlinear problems, a second class of problems involves spectral functions of the Laplacian. A unifying theme is the use of asymptotic methods. The project involves a graduate student.


The PI proposes to work on various problems in the area of partial differential equations with the unifying theme of using asymptotic methods. The development of techniques and the exploration of their applicability to problems on noncompact and singular spaces is expected to enhance the range of settings in which such problems of physical and geometric origin may be studied. These topics have been the subject of intense research activity. The PI has been very active in speaking in conferences and research programs, and funding will support such travel. Funding will also allow the PI to visit collaborators and to support the travel of collaborators to her home institution. Very importantly, it will also allow her to support a graduate student. The PI is involved in education at all levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the grant period, I published two papers, Kaehler-Einstein Metrics with Edge Singularities, with Rafe Mazzeo and Yanir A. Rubinstein, and Zeta Function on Surfaces of Revolution, with Klaus Kirsten and Tianshi Lu. Funding from the National Science Foundation also provided partial funding for three graduate students.

 

In Zeta Function of Self-Adjoint Operators on Surfaces of Revolution, my above-named collaborators and I continued earlier work on a zeta function which is a sum of powers of eigenvalues of the Laplacian. The prototype for such functions is the eponymously named Riemann zeta function. This is an extension to the complex plane of the p-series encountered by students of Calculus. It was the genius of  Riemann to perceive that this function illuminates deep properties of numbers, such as the distribution of primes. It also has applications to quantum physics. Remarkably, physicists have used the zeta function to make predictions that come within three percent of observed experimental data.

 

Among its various applications, the zeta function also encodes geometric information. The eigenvalues are solutions to differential equations which, because of the rotational symmetry, are ordinary differential equations. These solutions can almost never be calculated explicitly. We used asymptotic methods, such as the WKB method,  to determine convergence properties and to calculate certain important values and residues. These turned out to be geometric quantities associated to the surface - curvature, circumference of the cross section, and so on.

 

In Kaehler-Einstein Metrics with Edge Singularities, my co-authors and I determined conditions under which a metric of constant Ricci curvature exists on certain complex objects which contain singularities. The kinds of singularities we contemplated occur frequently in algebraic settings as well as in physical applications. The partial differential equation whose solution gives a Kaehler-Einstein metric, the Monge-Ampere equation, is fully nonlinear. The extension of methods first developed for linear equations into the nonlinear realm has generated considerable activity in recent years, and our paper was a contribution to this emerging understanding.

 

Support from this grant provided partial funding for three graduate students. This was of tremendous importance not just to the individual students, but also to the department and to the university.
